citations.narrative:
The licensee is conducting regulated activity at an unapproved site. The licensee stated that she has a breeding pair of
caracal cats at a friend's property in Alabama. These animals are paired up for breeding, and recently had offspring which
the licensee sold. The property in Alabama has not been approved for regulated activity by USDA officials. The licensee
has repeatedly been informed by USDA officials that no regulated activity may occur at unapproved locations. Inspection
and approval of locations (sites) where animals are housed is essential for ensuring animal welfare and compliance with
the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations. Correct by only conducting regulated activity (including breeding, selling, and
exhibiting AWA-covered animals) at sites/locations that have been inspected and approved by USDA officials.

Acquisition records for 1 kangaroo (obtained on 7/30/23), 3 coatis (obtained on 9/6/23), and 2 leopard cats (obtained on
7/22/23) do not contain the driver’s license number and state, or the vehicle tag number and state for the sellers/donors of
the animals. These sellers/donors do not have USDA licenses.
Acquisition records are necessary for accurate tracking of animals used in regulated activities to ensure their legal
acquisition, proper care, humane transportation, and to be able to track and trace animals in the case of an animal
disease outbreak or loss/theft.
Correct by maintaining records which fully and correctly disclose all information required by the AWA concerning animals
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in the facility’s possession or under the facility’s
control (including animals born); for unlicensed individuals the acquisition records must include vehicle number and state
and driver's license number and state (or state photo ID number). Correct by 10/19/23 for all future acquisition records.

Disposition records for 1 kangaroo and 1 coati indicate that these animals died but do no include dates of death.
Disposition records are necessary for accurate tracking of animals used in regulated activities to ensure their proper care,
humane transportation, and to be able to track and trace animals in the event of an animal disease outbreak or loss/theft.
Correct by maintaining records which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals which are transported,
sold, euthanized, died, or otherwise disposed of by the facility. Correct by 10/19/23 for all future disposition records.

The licensee failed to get health certificates for primates transported across state lines in commerce as required under the
Animal Welfare Act.
***The licensee acquired 1 juvenile female common marmoset from a seller in Florida and transported the animal to
Alabama. Once in Alabama, the licensee obtained a health certificate for the animal and traveled onward. The licensee
stated that she was unable to find a veterinarian to issue a health certificate in Florida at that time.
***The licensee acquired and transported 11 squirrel monkeys on 9/1/2023 with a health certificate that was issued on
8/21/2023 (11 days prior). The licensee transported the animals across multiple state lines in order to return home with
them.
Examination by a veterinarian and issuance of a health certificate within 10 days of transport is important for animal
health. Accepting non-human primates and transporting them in commerce without the required examinations and health
certificates may result in the transport of sick or injured animals, and may put the animals at the receiving facility at risk of
exposure to communicable diseases.
Correct by 10/19/23 for all future transports, only transporting non-human primates accompanied by a health certificate
that is executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian that is not more than 10 days prior.

citations.desc: Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers.
citations.narrative:
On 9/6/23 the licensee obtained 3 (1 male, 2 female) 4-week-old coatis from an unlicensed seller. The seller did not have
a 1-time variance for the sale of these animals and did not have a valid USDA license. The licensee’s acquisition records
for these animals contain no USDA license number. The licensee stated that she failed to verify USDA licensure for the
seller despite knowing that a USDA license is required to sell coatis and knowing how to use the USDA Public Search
Tool to verify licensure.
Animals sold by entities who are required to have a USDA license but who do not have a current, valid USDA license may
suffer from poor welfare due to the seller’s lack of compliance with Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations. Correct by
10/19/23, by obtaining animals only from persons or facilities that currently hold a valid licensed under the AWA, when
such licensure for the sale of the animals is required.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
Additional Inspectors:
Brittany Kessler, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.1(b)(1)  Repeat
   
Requirements and application 
The licensee is conducting regulated activity at an unapproved site. The licensee stated that she has a breeding pair of 
caracal cats at a friend's property in Alabama. These animals are paired up for breeding, and recently had offspring which 
the licensee sold. The property in Alabama has not been approved for regulated activity by USDA officials. The licensee 
has repeatedly been informed by USDA officials that no regulated activity may occur at unapproved locations. Inspection 
and approval of locations (sites) where animals are housed is essential for ensuring animal welfare and compliance with 
the Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations. Correct by only conducting regulated activity (including breeding, selling, and 
exhibiting AWA-covered animals) at sites/locations that have been inspected and approved by USDA officials. 
2.75(b)(1)(iii) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Acquisition records for 1 kangaroo (obtained on 7/30/23), 3 coatis (obtained on 9/6/23), and 2 leopard cats (obtained on 
7/22/23) do not contain the driver’s license number and state, or the vehicle tag number and state for the sellers/donors of 
the animals. These sellers/donors do not have USDA licenses.  
Acquisition records are necessary for accurate tracking of animals used in regulated activities to ensure their legal 
acquisition, proper care, humane transportation, and to be able to track and trace animals in the case of an animal 
disease outbreak or loss/theft. 
Correct by maintaining records which fully and correctly disclose all information required by the AWA concerning animals 
purchased or otherwise acquired, owned, held, leased, or otherwise in the facility’s possession or under the facility’s 
control (including animals born); for unlicensed individuals the acquisition records must include vehicle number and state 
and driver's license number and state (or state photo ID number). Correct by 10/19/23 for all future acquisition records. 
2.75(b)(1)(v) 
   
Records: Dealers and exhibitors. 
Disposition records for 1 kangaroo and 1 coati indicate that these animals died but do no include dates of death. 
Disposition records are necessary for accurate tracking of animals used in regulated activities to ensure their proper care, 
humane transportation, and to be able to track and trace animals in the event of an animal disease outbreak or loss/theft. 
Correct by maintaining records which fully and correctly disclose information concerning animals which are transported, 
sold, euthanized, died, or otherwise disposed of by the facility. Correct by 10/19/23 for all future disposition records.

2.78 
   
Health certification and identification. 
The licensee failed to get health certificates for primates transported across state lines in commerce as required under the 
Animal Welfare Act.  
***The licensee acquired 1 juvenile female common marmoset from a seller in Florida and transported the animal to 
Alabama. Once in Alabama, the licensee obtained a health certificate for the animal and traveled onward. The licensee 
stated that she was unable to find a veterinarian to issue a health certificate in Florida at that time. 
***The licensee acquired and transported 11 squirrel monkeys on 9/1/2023 with a health certificate that was issued on 
8/21/2023 (11 days prior). The licensee transported the animals across multiple state lines in order to return home with 
them. 
Examination by a veterinarian and issuance of a health certificate within 10 days of transport is important for animal 
health. Accepting non-human primates and transporting them in commerce without the required examinations and health 
certificates may result in the transport of sick or injured animals, and may put the animals at the receiving facility at risk of 
exposure to communicable diseases. 
Correct by 10/19/23 for all future transports, only transporting non-human primates accompanied by a health certificate 
that is executed and issued by a licensed veterinarian that is not more than 10 days prior. 
2.132(d)  Critical
   
Procurement of dogs, cats, and other animals; dealers. 
On 9/6/23 the licensee obtained 3 (1 male, 2 female) 4-week-old coatis from an unlicensed seller. The seller did not have 
a 1-time variance for the sale of these animals and did not have a valid USDA license. The licensee’s acquisition records 
for these animals contain no USDA license number. The licensee stated that she failed to verify USDA licensure for the 
seller despite knowing that a USDA license is required to sell coatis and knowing how to use the USDA Public Search 
Tool to verify licensure.  
Animals sold by entities who are required to have a USDA license but who do not have a current, valid USDA license may 
suffer from poor welfare due to the seller’s lack of compliance with Animal Welfare Act (AWA) regulations. Correct by 
10/19/23, by obtaining animals only from persons or facilities that currently hold a valid licensed under the AWA, when 
such licensure for the sale of the animals is required. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Brittany Kessler, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
